content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. I can identify several potential lymph nodes, characterized by their ovoid shape and dense, basophilic (purple) staining. The most prominent and largest lymph node is located in the upper left quadrant. Other smaller, basophilic fragments are scattered, which could also be lymph nodes or parts of them. The remaining tissue appears to be fibro-adipose tissue. My initial impression is that this slide contains lymph nodes from a colorectal cancer resection, which need to be assessed for metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into the area marked by the green box because it highlights the largest and most well-defined lymph node on the slide. When evaluating a cancer case for staging, a systematic examination of all lymph nodes is critical. Starting with the largest node is a logical approach. The dense cellularity seen at this low power could represent either a reactive process or a large metastatic deposit. Therefore, high-power examination is essential to assess the architecture and cytology to rule in or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist must systematically examine every piece of tissue on the slide that could represent a lymph node or a tumor deposit. The area highlighted by the green box is a small, distinct cluster of purple cells located within the adipose tissue in the lower-central part of the slide. Such an area is suspicious and must be investigated at higher magnification to determine its nature. It could be a very small lymph node, a benign lymphoid aggregate, or, importantly, a small metastatic deposit (tumor nodule). Therefore, zooming in is essential to look for the characteristic features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is centered on a distinct, dense, basophilic aggregate located within the tissue fragment at the bottom right. This structure is clearly identifiable as a lymph node on low power. In the context of staging for colorectal cancer, every single lymph node must be meticulously examined at high magnification to either confirm or rule out the presence of metastatic tumor cells. This area is a mandatory point of interest for that reason. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task in this case is to identify all lymph nodes and examine them for metastatic cancer, which is critical for staging. The area indicated by the green box is a densely cellular, basophilic tissue fragment. At low power, it is a clear candidate for being a lymph node. Its architecture appears somewhat irregular and effaced, which raises suspicion. I would zoom into this area to confirm it is a lymph node and then to meticulously search for any non-lymphoid, atypical epithelial cells (metastatic carcinoma) that would signify a positive node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is a distinct tissue fragment located in the upper right part of the slide that contains a dense, dark purple (basophilic) cellular area. This appearance is characteristic of lymphoid tissue. As a pathologist, my protocol is to examine every potential lymph node on the slide at high magnification to search for metastatic tumor cells. This fragment is one of the candidates that must be thoroughly evaluated. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the classic features of lymphoid tissue. The architecture is characterized by numerous, crowded lymphoid follicles, which vary in size and shape. The follicles are composed of a dense population of small, round lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of malignant epithelial cells, or necrosis that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma from a colorectal primary. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node with marked follicular hyperplasia, and it is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see mature adipose tissue (large, white, empty-looking cells) and a small, somewhat fragmented aggregate of cells. These cells are predominantly small with dark, round nuclei, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or desmoplastic stromal reaction. My impression is that this is a benign lymphoid aggregate, possibly a fragment of a very small lymph node. The pathologist likely zoomed in to rule out a small metastasis, and based on this view, this particular area appears to be benign.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms this is a lymph node that has been partially replaced by a malignant infiltrate. I can see residual normal lymphoid tissue (dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes) being effaced by irregular nests and glandular structures composed of atypical epithelial cells. These malignant cells have large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary. My impression is that this is a positive (metastatic) lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. This confirms the tissue is a lymph node. The normal nodal architecture, such as distinct germinal centers and sinuses, appears to be effaced or obscured by this dense lymphoid population. There are some interspersed pink fibrous septa and small blood vessels. I do not see any definitive nests, glands, or single files of large, atypical epithelial cells with pleomorphic nuclei and prominent nucleoli that would be characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. The impression from this specific field of view is that of a lymph node with reactive changes causing architectural effacement. However, without examining the entire node at high magnification, metastasis (especially micrometastasis) cannot be completely ruled out.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see lymphoid tissue on the right, characterized by a dense sheet of small, dark, round cells (lymphocytes). On the left, there is mature adipose tissue (fat). The interface between the lymphoid tissue and the fat is irregular and infiltrative, meaning the lymphocytes are extending into and surrounding the individual fat cells. This is an abnormal finding, as a normal lymph node typically has a smooth, fibrous capsule. While I see this architectural abnormality, I do not see definite clusters of large, atypical epithelial cells with glandular formation that would confirm metastatic adenocarcinoma in this specific field of view. My impression is that this is a lymph node with an infiltrative border (extranodal extension of lymphoid cells), which is suspicious. I would need to carefully scan the entire node at high power to look for any hidden tumor deposits before making a final diagnosis of positive or negative for metastasis.
